<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 222, 432]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 434, 880, 636]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.- You should use a calculator where appropriate.- You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.- Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 664, 212, 678]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 680, 728, 711]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 50.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 72, 96, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 72, 912, 91]]<|/det|>
The random variables \(X\) and \(Y\) have the independent distributions N(44, 16) and N(30, 9) respectively.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 103, 282, 121]]<|/det|>
Find \(\mathrm{P}(X - Y < 15)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 103, 920, 121]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 72, 785, 90]]<|/det|>
A researcher records the time, \(T\) seconds, taken by adults to complete a questionnaire.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 103, 918, 135]]<|/det|>
The results for a random sample of 60 adults who completed the questionnaire this year are summarised as follows.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[297, 147, 700, 166]]<|/det|>
\[n = 60\qquad \Sigma t = 3678\qquad \Sigma t^2 = 226\,313.36\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 180, 144, 198]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 180, 918, 198]]<|/det|>
Find an unbiased estimate of \(\mathrm{E}(T)\), and show that an unbiased estimate of \(\mathrm{Var}(T)\) is 14.44. [3]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 212, 917, 952]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 72, 553, 88]]<|/det|>
<pre>In the past, the population mean time was 62.4 seconds.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 103, 146, 121]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 103, 918, 135]]<|/det|>
Test at the \(2\%\) significance level whether the population mean time for this year is less than 62.4 seconds.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 117, 918, 135]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 148, 917, 666]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 675, 144, 693]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 675, 918, 708]]<|/det|>
State, with a reason, whether it was necessary to use the Central Limit Theorem in your answer to part (b).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 692, 918, 710]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 723, 917, 925]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 522, 90]]<|/det|>
The random variable \(X\) has the distribution \(\mathrm{Po}(1.5)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 146, 121]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 103, 280, 121]]<|/det|>
Find \(\mathrm{P}(X \geqslant 3)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 103, 920, 121]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 133, 918, 460]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 475, 148, 492]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 475, 920, 492]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that the sum of three independent values of \(X\) is between 3 and 5 inclusive.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 491, 920, 509]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 521, 918, 945]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 72, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
The sum of a large number, \(n\), of values of \(X\) is denoted by \(T\). Using a suitable approximation, it was found that \(\mathrm{P}(T > 330) = 0.0391\), correct to 3 significant figures.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 119, 312, 135]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(n\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 119, 920, 135]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 148, 917, 952]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 94, 87]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 146, 87]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 96, 715, 260]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 275, 918, 324]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the graph of the probability density function, f, of a random variable \(X\). The graph is a straight line from (0, \(a\)) to (2, \(b\)), where \(a\) and \(b\) are positive constants. Elsewhere, \(\mathrm{f}(x) = 0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 338, 180, 356]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 338, 359, 356]]<|/det|>
Show that \(b = 1 - a\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 338, 918, 356]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 492, 180, 510]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 492, 534, 510]]<|/det|>
Given that \(\mathrm{E}(X) = 1.2\) , find the value of \(a\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 492, 918, 510]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 148, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 72, 643, 90]]<|/det|>
A random variable \(T\) has probability density function given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[351, 103, 645, 148]]<|/det|>
\[\mathrm{g}(t) = \begin{cases} \frac{1}{2}\cos t & -\frac{1}{2}\pi \leqslant t \leqslant \frac{1}{2}\pi , \\ 0 & \text{otherwise.} \end{cases}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 163, 542, 182]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(c\) such that \(\mathsf{P}(-c < t < c) = \frac{1}{2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 163, 920, 182]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 196, 917, 935]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 92, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 72, 918, 121]]<|/det|>
Amir believes that \(20\%\) of the students at his college are left-handed. His friend believes that the true proportion, \(p\) , is less than \(20\%\) . Amir plans to use the binomial distribution to test the null hypothesis, \(\mathrm{H}_0\colon p = 0.2\) , against the alternative hypothesis, \(\mathrm{H}_1\colon p< 0.2\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 134, 918, 167]]<|/det|>
He decides to choose 35 students at random. If 3 or fewer of these students are left-handed, Amir will reject his belief.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 180, 146, 198]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 180, 450, 197]]<|/det|>
Find the significance level of the test.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 180, 918, 198]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 212, 917, 730]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 737, 146, 756]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 737, 450, 756]]<|/det|>
State the probability of a Type I error.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 737, 918, 756]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 475, 88]]<|/det|>
<pre>It is now given that the true value of \(p\) is 0.05.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 144, 120]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 103, 455, 120]]<|/det|>
Find the probability of a Type II error.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 103, 920, 120]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 133, 917, 945]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 72, 918, 106]]<|/det|>
Nikki is investigating the views of students at her school about the school sports facilities. She plans to give a survey to a sample of students.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 119, 918, 151]]<|/det|>
Nikki's friend says, “This survey is about sports facilities, so you should choose a sample of students from the school sports teams.”

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 165, 144, 183]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 165, 620, 183]]<|/det|>
State, with a reason, whether you agree with Nikki's friend.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 165, 918, 183]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 288, 918, 322]]<|/det|>
<pre>Nikki chooses an appropriate random sample of 60 students. She finds that 45 of these students think that the sports facilities are good.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 335, 146, 354]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 335, 918, 368]]<|/det|>
Calculate an approximate \(95\%\) confidence interval for the proportion of students who think that the sports facilities are good.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 350, 918, 368]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 381, 917, 925]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 72, 918, 104]]<|/det|>
For a different investigation, Nikki uses another large random sample to calculate a \(99\%\) confidence interval and an \(x\%\) confidence interval.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 120, 834, 135]]<|/det|>
The width of the \(99\%\) confidence interval is double the width of the \(x\%\) confidence interval.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 149, 918, 166]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 173, 917, 952]]<|/det|>
